subject: Max Headroom Returns
event: Remember Max Headroom? Sure you do. If you're old enough. M-M-Max was a king, once upon a time. Twenty minutes into the future... thirty years into the past... it was 1987, and Max was the hottest television personality in the world, with the hottest television show. Actually, he had several shows. He started out in the Uk introducing music videos. Then he got his own talk show, also in the UK. And then a ground-breaking British television movie. New Coke made him their official spokesman. Then Max crossed the Atlantic to get his own sf show on ABC. He made the cover of NEWSWEEK, was parodied on the cover of MAD, did a guest appearance with David Letterman. Alas, alack, Max Headroom's reign as the king of popular media proved as short lived as New Coke. His series on ABC was hailed as innovative, startling, ground-breaking, original... like nothing else on television... the first cyberpunk television show... but it proved to be way WAY ahead of its time, starting strong and falling fast, surviving for only two short semi-seasons, an initial run of six episodes, and a second season of seven. Then ABC pulled the plug, and Max vanished from the airwaves, surviving only in the hearts and minds of science fiction fans. Thirty years have come and gone since that glorious year of 1987, and once again we're going twenty minutes into the future... in Santa Fe, at least. So mark the dates May 13 - May 20 down on your calendars, and be sure to swing by the Jean Cocteau Cinema. That's the week we're having our M-M-M-MAXATHON!!! Yes, that's right. We've having a whole week of Max, to celebrate his 30th anniversary. We'll be screening all fourteen episodes of his show: the original British pilot, "Twenty Minutes Into the Future," and the American remake of same, plus every one of the ABC hours that followed. You saw them once on your little-bitty 1987 tv set. Now see them again on the Cocteau's big medium-sized screen. With our world famous popcorn... and maybe we can even find some New Coke! Some very special guests will be coming to Santa Fe to help us celebrate the anniversary. Head writer STEVE ROBERTS, who scripted the British pilot and crossed the pond to head the writing staff for the ABC show, will be flying in to join us, and MICHAEL CASSUTT, another of Max's writer producers will be with us start to finish. After thirty years, they're ready to spill all the secrets. But wait, there's more... Max himself is coming too. Yes, MATT FREWER, the one and only Max Headroom, will be on hand for the last three days of the M-M-M-Maxathon. Oh, and one more thing. We'll also be featuring, for the very first time anywhere, two Max Headroom episodes that have never been seen or heard before anywhere, two episodes written by a guy you won't find listed anywhere in the credits for the show: me. Yep. That's right. MAX HEADROOM is the great "what if" in my own television career. For me, MAX came along after my stint on TWILIGHT ZONE and before BEAUTY AND THE BEAST. When ABC first greenlit the US show, they ordered six original scripts to follow the pilot, almost all of which ended up getting assigned to writers just coming off TZ. I was one of those. Mine was supposedly to be... hmmmmm, let me see now... the fourth episode of the series. My title was "Mister Meat." Now, TV writing in those days was a two-step process: "story with option to teleplay," they called it. You wrote a 'story,' a short plot outline with all the major beats and characters. Then, when the showrunners, studio, and network all approved it, you went on to write the teleplay. "Mister Meat" never got that far, alas. The showrunners and my fellow Maxxies loved it, as I recall, but when ABC saw the story they reacted with horror. Way too disturbing and offensive, they announced, driving a spike firmly through my concept and sending me on my way. Which I why I never got hired onto MAX HEADROOM and wound up on staff on BEAUTY AND THE BEAST instead. I got a second chance when MAX was picked up for a second season, however. As a freelancer, I got the choice assignment of writing the Christmas episode. And this time I went to town. Wrote the story, rewrote the story, wrote the teleplay, revised the teleplay. "Xmas" was the title of the episode, and it got as far as pre-production... And then the show was cancelled. Rather suddenly and unceremoniously, I must say. America was spared from celebrating Xmas with Max. Ah, but with strange aeons even death may die... and like all good writers, I never throw anything away. So as part of our Jean Cocteau M-M-M-Maxathon, the world will meet "Mister Meat" and "Xmas" for the first time. "Mister Meat" is just a short treatment, so I will be reading it myself on the third day of the marathon, in the slot it would have filled if it had been filmed. Come and hear the episode that ABC deemed too offensive and disgusting for Ronald Reagan's America. As for "Xmas"... hell, we have a whole finished script of that one, so we're going to be performing it, live, on the tiny little stage at the Jean Cocteau. Lenore Gallegos will direct, and the parts of Edison Carter, Bryce, Theora, Blank Reg, Max himself, and all the rest of the gang from Network 23 and the ZikZak corporation will be performed by a fearless cast of local actors... whoever ends up playing Max will HAVE to fearless, to play the part with Matt Frewer in the audience. May 20. Be there, or forever rue your absence. Oh, and as usual, the screenings will all be FREE. ((But we will charge admission for the performance of "Xmas")) May 13-14-15-16-17-18-19-20. Don't m-m-m-miss it.

comments.article: I remember Max fondly. I loved the show. As a budding liberal, I though Max was a critique of the Reagan years written specifically for me. ABC broke my heart when they fuddled around with it, then cancelled it. Welcome to the real world, kid. It sucked. I wanted my fake one back. Still, I guess it all worked out, sort of. Thanks for letting us know about your history with it. Always a pleasure.
comments.subject: To the Max

comments.article: Any long lost "Falcon crest" episodes you wrote that never made it? Learn something new everyday. Also, I owned a MHR t-shirt at one point in my adolescence.
How do you get the rights to do this?
Loved Max.  It was clever and funny.  I remember how disappointed I was when it went away.
I'm sooo in the wrong state yet again! ðŸ˜­
The wonderfully quirky Max Headroom. Great show, although to this day I can't watch Matt Frewer without hearing Max's electronic stutter in my head.
exactly... Although I do remember not quite understanding where the show was going...

I was too young in the mid 1980s to have much memory of or affection for Max. Too busy watching THUNDERCATS and G.I. JOE.

But reading about the show, it sounds like a premise that would fit the era we live in very nicely.

Maybe you can follow up on this by showing THEY LIVE for the full 'Reagan era fiction that still feels timely' experience.
They Live! Campy as it was, it has one of the best fight scenes ever, between the Roddy Piper and Keith David.
Oh, wow. I may have to figure out a way to be there for that. Thirty years, though?? Impossible. That would mean my 30 yr high school reunion is this year, and I completely deny that possibility...
You wrote for Max Headroom? How many people died in these hidden episodes?
comments.subject: re: really

comments.upictitle: Prof. Jeremy M. R. F. Chesterfield-Pickles III: Holmes
comments.article:
I remember it well...

Network 23; the body bank; raking/rake-boarding; Missile Mike; "Losing a viddy cam at Network 23 is a hanging offense!"

I so wish I could take a trip down there for this...
In which 80s movie or videoclip (ir both) Max made a cameo? I have a vague memory of It.
comments.subject: They made a cameo?

comments.article:
Max actually made a cameo in a 2015 movie: PIXELS, in which a probe sent up in 1982 somehow contained the 80's Greatest Hits, including Max, who did not yet exist.

Not his finest hour, I assure you.
comments.subject: Re: They made a cameo?

comments.article: Do you remember the famous Max Headroom hacking incident, when some unknown pranksters hacked into the signal of a couple of Chicago TV stations and broadcast their own Max spoof? So creepy, and so intriguing - I would love to finally find out who did it! The mystery remains unsolved to this day... :)
Cooool! Wish I could be there! Passing this on...

comments.upictitle: Sean P. Fodera: Sean P. Lego
comments.article:
I'd love to be there for the whole week. I loved that show. I even went to a Halloween party as Max, with a huge latex Max mask (I loved the fact that the molded shades fit right over my glasses). Great show. And it turned me into a fan of Matt Frewer.

Did you know that Max even appeared on Sesame Street? That's how big the character was.

I'd love to see them bring him back, but a reboot wouldn't be the same.

I hope the event is a big success.

What's the chance you'll incorporate the footage from the signal intrusion hack into the event? It'd make an...appropriate... intermission!

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Headroom_broadcast_signal_intrusion

LOVED Max Headroom!

Too bad I live so far away...I'd *so* be there for the screenings of this show!

So much happens at JCC I want to see - maybe I'm in the wrong place, as others have mentioned here. The winters are nice in NM compared to Canada after all...plus I did take my first steps in Tuscon so I'm told.

Max Hedroom was everywhere when I entered high school in the mid/late 80s. It still bakes my brain a little when I think that the same person who wrote so many of the WC stories, the Song of Ice/Fire in its varying forms, Beauty/Beast, as well as some Max stuff (and so much else). Very diverse.
comments.subject: JCC

comments.article:
Why does Last of the Giants match up with many parts of Piano Man by Billy Joel?
Link related

http://vocaroo.com/i/s13m5BY05YKz
comments.subject: Last of the Piano Men

comments.article: Grrm I worked on Max too after TZ with Phil D and had saved every episode script in a box for years...and ...gasp threw them out...Say hi to Steve if u get this...we worked together at WB after Max. This is so great you are resurrecting the show!! Waaay ahead of its time..you were too cool for ABC! Sheila Wenz from ye old TZ days!
comments.subject: Blipverts

comments.article: I commented on the your later entry before I got back and saw this one. I still think Max Headroom was awesome and a highlight of my middle school years! I'm sorry you didn't get your xmas episode produced! If I didn't live in Ohio, I would be VERY tempted to come to this.

What a great story , I'm from Birmingham England , this guy used to freak me out as a kid . He was way ahead of time , you're definitely right there ! It's amazing how your connected to it , small world huh ?!!
When I was 14 I won a Max Headroom skateboard. I am now 43 and I still have the deck. I will never get rid of it. Special times and memories. Thanks, George!
nice!
